Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Efficient Energy-Aware Web Browsing in Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Web browsing is one of the most common and important services provided by smartphones. However, it currently suffers from long delays and creates a huge drain on the battery lifetime of smartphones. These limitations are caused by complex interactions between the processing flow in mobile web browsers and specialized characteristics of the wireless radio interface, and by the processing limitations of the smartphones. This project addresses these limitations by focusing on three intertwined issues: (i) various techniques to reorganize the computation sequence of the web browser to let the wireless radio interface enter sleep earlier, are designed, implemented and evaluated; (ii) practical data mining based methods are introduced to predict the user viewing time of webpages and determine when the smartphone should switch to low power state, considering the resource limitations of the smartphone and various tradeoffs between delay and power; and (iii) a new architecture is proposed to shift the computing from smartphones to the virtual-machine based proxy to address the computation limitations in smartphones considering scalability issues and bandwidth constraints. This project will make significant theoretical and technical advances on reducing the power consumption and access delay of web browsing in wireless networks. The success of this project will affect many people's daily life, making smartphones last longer and web browsing faster. The results of the project will be disseminated widely through high quality publications and presentations. The proposed research will also be integrated with the education curricula at the Pennsylvania State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Web browsing is one of the most common and important services provided by smartphones. However, it currently suffers from long delays and creates a huge drain on the battery lifetime of smartphones. These limitations are caused by complex interactions between the processing flow in mobile web browsers and specialized characteristics of the wireless radio interface, and by the processing limitations of the smartphones. Through this project, various techniques have been developed to address these limitations.

We have designed, implemented and evaluated techniques to reorganize the computation sequence of the web browser so that the wireless radio interface can enter sleep earlier to save energy.  Experimental results show that our approach can significantly reduce the power consumption of smartphone during web browsing, and reduce the webpage loading time. We have introduced a practical data mining based method to predict the user reading time of webpages, based on which the smartphone can switch to low power state when the user viewing time is longer than a threshold. Moreover, interest based method have been proposed to improve the prediction accuracy. Experimental results show that the proposed technique can significantly save energy and reduce the web browsing delay.

We have discovered that another key reason for the long delay and high power consumption in web browsing is the local computation limitations on smartphones.  To address this issue, we proposed a new architecture which shifts the computing from smartphones to the cloud. To realize the goal of this new architecture, we have addressed the scalability issues, optimized the cloud performance, and designed protocols to address the poor network conditions at the smartphone.

Through extensive real measurements in multiple cities, we observe that mobile devices (nodes) within an area may have different service quality (e.g., a node may consume multiple times of energy and delay to download the same amount of data), especially when different service providers are used. We proposed and implemented a data offloading framework to offload network tasks to neighboring nodes with better throughput, to save energy and reduce delay. This result has been generated and extended to reduce energy and delay for a group of nearby users who access various webpages using smartphones, where the energy and delay can be reduced by aggregating the data traffic of multiple nodes using their P2P interfaces such as WiFi direct.

Many of the research results have been integrated with the education curricula at the Pennsylvania State University. The project has supported three PhD students working on their dissertations and two undergraduate students have been supported through an REU supplement.  The involvement of the graduate/undergraduate students will prepare them for leadership roles in computer science research, academia, and industry.
